coverage: Nahum delivers a concentrated taunt-and-woe oracle announcing YHWH’s judgment on Nineveh/Assyria as a divine warrior who storms, floods, and burns the predatory empire. The book contrasts Jonah’s reprieve with final ruin, frames justice as comfort for Judah/Zion, and deploys dense metaphor (lions, harlot, locusts) within a liturgical theophany and possible acrostic hymn (1:2–8). Historically situated around the fall of Nineveh (612 BCE) with Babylonian and Median forces, the book functions canonically as a paradigm of God’s retributive justice and refuge for the oppressed, echoed in later apocalyptic idioms.
id_scheme: Cross-book stable by (type+primary-slug) + deterministic hash; alias reuse for shared entities.

entries.name: Nahum of Elkosh
entries.place: Elkosh (uncertain; proposals include Judah or Galilee)
entries.blurb: The eponymous prophet whose oracle concentrates on Nineveh’s downfall. His name (“comfort”) frames judgment as consolation for Judah. Literary voice alternates between hymn (1:2–8), divine decree, and taunt/woe over tyrannical Assyria.

entries.name: YHWH (the LORD)
entries.blurb: Covenant LORD revealed as avenger and refuge: slow to anger yet great in power. Appears in theophanic storm/flood, opposing Assyria’s pride while sheltering those who take refuge in him.

entries.name: Assyria
entries.blurb: Imperial power depicted as predatory lions and a harlot city. Once an instrument of judgment, it becomes the judged, emblematic of tyrants brought low by divine justice.

entries.name: Nineveh
entries.place: Capital of Assyria on the Tigris
entries.blurb: Focus of Nahum’s oracle. Once repentant in Jonah, now portrayed as blood-soaked, deceitful, and doomed. Its walls, gates, idols, and treasures are plundered; shame replaces glory.

entries.name: Judah
entries.blurb: Recipient of good news: festivals and vows restored; Assyria’s yoke broken. Nahum frames judgment on Nineveh as pastoral comfort for Judah.

entries.name: Israel
entries.blurb: Mentioned in restoration language (2:2). The oracle resonates beyond Judah to the wider covenant identity.

entries.name: Nations
entries.blurb: International witnesses who clap at Nineveh’s fall. The scope underscores public, exemplary justice.

entries.name: Babylonians
entries.blurb: Historical agent in Nineveh’s fall (612 BCE) alongside the Medes. Not named in Nahum but essential context for the oracle’s fulfillment.

entries.name: Medes
entries.blurb: Allied with Babylon in the historical destruction of Nineveh; part of the geopolitical backdrop of Nahum’s prophecy.

entries.name: Zion
entries.blurb: Site of the ‘good news’ announcement: festivals resumed, vows kept, feet of the herald on the mountains.

entries.name: Jerusalem
entries.blurb: The communal center of worship restored as Assyria’s threat is removed.

entries.name: Daughter Nineveh
entries.blurb: Nineveh depicted as a woman exposed and shamed—an image of judgment fitting her predatory seductions and violence.

entries.name: Daughter Zion
entries.blurb: The rejoicing community hearing ‘good news’ of liberation when Assyria’s yoke is broken.

entries.name: The Harlot City
entries.blurb: Nineveh as a seductive yet violent courtesan whose sorceries and betrayals are exposed.

entries.name: The Lion’s Den
entries.blurb: Assyrian kings and elites likened to lions who preyed on nations; their den is burned and emptied by divine decree.

entries.name: Locust/Grasshopper Swarm
entries.blurb: Nineveh’s merchants and soldiers multiply like locusts yet flee when the sun rises; their strength proves transient.

entries.name: Flood/Overflowing torrent
entries.blurb: A weapon of YHWH’s judgment; river gates open, undermining Nineveh’s defenses. Evokes exodus and creation-chaos motifs.

entries.name: Fire/Consuming flame
entries.blurb: Burns the lion’s lair and devours defenses; paired with sword imagery for total desolation.

entries.name: Earthquake/Whirlwind/Storm
entries.blurb: Creation convulses at YHWH’s approach; mountains quake, rocks shatter—cosmic-scale sovereignty over history.

entries.name: Taunt Song
entries.blurb: Mocking lament over a toppled tyrant, reversing imperial boasts into shame. Central to Nahum’s rhetoric.

entries.name: Woe Oracle
entries.blurb: Prophetic ‘woe’ formula indicting Nineveh’s bloodguilt, lies, and plunder.

entries.name: Acrostic Hymn (Nahum 1)
entries.blurb: Scholars detect alphabetic sequencing in 1:2–8, a hymn extolling God’s justice and refuge; establishes the theological key for the book.

entries.name: Nineveh’s walls
entries.blurb: Monumental defenses imagined as ripe figs; they collapse when shaken, signaling the end of Assyrian security.

entries.name: Nineveh’s gates
entries.blurb: ‘River gates’ open; the city’s entry points fail, exposing it to invasion and flood.

entries.name: River gates
entries.blurb: Engineering tied to the Khosr/Tigris; when breached, they become conduits of judgment rather than protection.

entries.name: Chariots like torches
entries.blurb: Vivid battle scene: chariots flashing, racing through streets; either Assyrian defenders or attackers—either way, chaos and doom.

entries.name: Siege ramps
entries.blurb: Assault infrastructure signals relentless pressure against Nineveh’s walls.

entries.name: Idols of Nineveh
entries.blurb: YHWH decrees their desecration—religious collapse accompanies political ruin.

entries.name: Temple(s) of Assyria
entries.blurb: Cult centers implicated in imperial violence; their names are cut off.

entries.name: Plunder/Treasure
entries.blurb: The wealth amassed by predation becomes prey for invaders; heart-melting despair replaces luxury.

entries.name: Bloodshed
entries.blurb: Core charge: Nineveh is built on violence; prophetic justice targets structural bloodguilt.

entries.name: Shame/Exposure motif
entries.blurb: Honor-shame reversal: the tyrant is publicly humiliated; no healer, no comforter remains.

entries.name: Hooks and yokes
entries.blurb: Symbols of deportation and bondage; Judah’s yoke is shattered while enemies are led away with hooks.

entries.name: Refuge/Stronghold
aka: Stronghold in the day of trouble
entries.blurb: Counterpoint to wrath: those who take refuge in YHWH find protection amid upheaval.

entries.name: Good news to Zion
entries.blurb: Liberation proclamation: imperial threat removed, worship restored—an archetype for later ‘gospel’ language.

entries.name: Festivals & vows (Judah)
entries.blurb: Cultic life resumes under divine protection; liturgical stability expresses social healing.

entries.name: Yoke broken
entries.blurb: Emancipation image: the instruments of oppression are destroyed by divine action.

entries.name: The Breaker
entries.blurb: Title-like image for the one who bursts bonds and opens the way; in Nahum the function is carried by YHWH’s warrior theophany.

entries.name: Scatterer at the gates
entries.blurb: Personified invader whom YHWH uses to bring Nineveh low; calls Judah to keep feasts while enemies are scattered.

entries.name: Watchmen/Heralds
entries.blurb: Figures who announce and guard—vehicles of ‘good news’ and signals of impending judgment.

entries.name: Fortress/Stronghold images
entries.blurb: The city’s strength proves illusory; fig-trees whose fruit falls when shaken.

entries.name: Desertion/Panic
entries.blurb: Nineveh’s people flee; officials sleep; mercenaries vanish—symbolic of hollow power.

entries.name: Sleep of the shepherds
entries.blurb: The ruling class lies inert when vigilance is required; the flock is scattered on the mountains.

entries.name: Assyrian kings (lion line)
entries.blurb: Royal house caricatured as lions who devoured prey for their cubs; their den is torched by YHWH.

entries.name: Babylonian commanders
entries.blurb: Historical actors in Nineveh’s siege; evocative background to the ‘scatterer’ and ‘flood’ motifs.

entries.name: Median commanders
entries.blurb: Allied leadership with Babylon; their presence explains the relentless pressure on Nineveh’s walls.

entries.name: Merchants of Nineveh
entries.blurb: Once numerous as stars, they vanish like locusts when judgment heat rises—profit proves ephemeral.

entries.name: Soldiers/Guards of Nineveh
entries.blurb: Crimson shields and flashing chariots project menace, yet they reel and stumble; finally they melt away.

entries.name: Refugees/Survivors
entries.blurb: The city’s populace flees like a pool draining; human cost surfaces behind imperial spectacle.

entries.name: Sword
entries.blurb: Paired with fire against locust-like hosts; emblem of inexorable judgment.

entries.name: Shields (crimson)
entries.blurb: Visual marker of battle-readiness that ultimately fails to save the city.

entries.name: Charioteers
entries.blurb: Agents of urban chaos; speed and shine become omens of collapse rather than security.

entries.name: Siege towers
entries.blurb: Protective structures for assault forces; their approach signals Nineveh’s end.

entries.name: Palace
entries.blurb: When river gates open, the palace totters—palatial glory cannot withstand divine flood.

entries.name: Treasury
entries.blurb: Storehouses of silver and gold—emptied; hearts melt, knees tremble.

entries.name: Nobles/Courtiers
entries.blurb: Elites scramble and then sleep; the collapse is administrative as well as military.

entries.name: Sorceries
entries.blurb: Nineveh’s manipulative arts—political/spiritual seduction—draw divine exposure and contempt.

entries.name: Chains/Bonds
entries.blurb: Concrete tokens of subjugation; divine action shatters them for Judah.

entries.name: Exile/Deportation
entries.blurb: Nineveh’s tool becomes its fate; the city’s inhabitants are carried off, infants dashed—grim mirror justice.

entries.name: Gates of the rivers
entries.blurb: Poetic doublet for ‘river gates’; emphasizes watery breach as decisive moment.

entries.name: Overthrow (complete)
entries.blurb: Decreed finality: no second repentance arc; Nineveh’s wound is incurable.

entries.name: Refuge rhetoric
entries.blurb: Pastoral center of the book: wrath and refuge together narrate God’s character and care.

entries.name: Vanity of power
entries.blurb: A wisdom-like verdict on empire: predation seems secure until divine judgment exposes fragility.

entries.name: Public laughter
entries.blurb: Communal mockery marks tyrant’s end; the nations applaud the justice they longed for.

entries.name: Woe-lament structure
entries.blurb: Combines indictment, exposure, and pronouncement of doom—shaping how the oracle is performed/heard.

entries.name: Herald on the mountains
entries.blurb: Iconic image of beautiful feet bringing peace; later reused in New Testament proclamation.

entries.name: Assyrian captives
entries.blurb: As Nineveh once deported others, so it becomes the captive—lex talionis of history under God.

entries.name: Ravening lions
entries.blurb: Extended pride-of-lions metaphor for Assyrian elites whose den is consumed.

entries.name: Fig trees—ripe fruit
entries.blurb: Nineveh’s strongholds fall like ripe figs—ease of collapse belies prior boasting.

entries.name: Water-pool (draining)
entries.blurb: Population and resolve ebb away; the city cannot be rallied despite commands to ‘stand!’

entries.name: Innumerable killed
entries.blurb: Graphic aftermath underscores moral horror of Nineveh’s career and fall.

entries.name: Harlot’s sorceries
entries.blurb: Political seduction and coercion under religious veneer; draws judgment for ensnaring nations.

entries.name: No-Amon (Thebes) parallel
entries.blurb: If Thebes, fortified by the Nile, fell, how much more Nineveh—scriptural reasoning by precedent.

entries.name: Pride/Boast
entries.blurb: Assyria’s hubris meets the divine ‘Behold, I am against you’—the covenant lawsuit climax.

entries.name: “Behold, I am against you”
entries.blurb: YHWH’s adversative oracle formula; guarantees defeat irrespective of military calculus.

entries.name: End of name
entries.blurb: Memory, dynasty, and cultic prestige erased—total de-legitimization of Assyria’s legacy.

entries.name: No healer
entries.blurb: The malady is terminal; no remedy remains—judgment’s finality stressed.
